history.content: Whether the workload is too much is dependent on the person; I will say that the workload of those classes will be comparable, maybe slighter greater than what you are doing right now (though I'm guessing on the math upper div).  So I would start off taking all three, and then drop one if need be.  I'm guessing you are a sophomore (since you took an RC), so I'd say that if you are potentially interested in circuits or device physics, you should definitely take 105 earlier rather than later so that you can progress in the field while at cal (105 is really the basics of circuits, and 16 the basics of the basics).

Whether the workload is too much is dependent on the person; I will say that the workload of those classes will be comparable, maybe slighter greater than what you are doing right now (though I'm guessing on the math upper div)- note though that if you got into 126, that's like winning the lottery based on the enrollment demand for it.  So I would start off taking all three, and then drop one if need be.  I'm guessing you are a sophomore (since you took an RC), so I'd say that if you are potentially interested in circuits or device physics, you should definitely take 105 earlier rather than later so that you can progress in the field while at cal (105 is really the basics of circuits, and 16 the basics of the basics).

Whether the workload is too much is dependent on the person; I will say that the workload of those classes will be comparable, maybe slighter greater than what you are doing right now (though I'm guessing on the math upper div)- note though that if you got into 126, that's like winning the lottery based on the enrollment demand for it.  So I would start off taking all three, and then drop one if need be.  I'm guessing you are a sophomore (since you took an RC), so I'd say that if you are potentially interested in circuits or device physics, you should definitely take 105 earlier rather than later so that you can progress in the field while at cal (105 is really the basics of circuits, and 16 the basics of the basics).

Was just wondering if the above workload is too much? This semester I took 61C + 70 + a math upper div + my RC breadth requirement and I have been struggling. Is the above requirement more than, less or about equal to the amount of work I am currently doing. The main thing that is killing me this semester is the amount of class I have to go to, rather than the actual workload? Also would be helpful if there was a note set I could review for any of the classes during winter break.
history.subject: EE 105 + CS 170 + EECS 126
